reference.shortdesc: Required cleanup sections are placeholders for migrated elements that cannot be appropriately tagged without manual intervention, or for content that must be cleaned up before publishing.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: As the element name implies, the intent for authors is to clean up the contained material and eventually remove the required-cleanup element.

section.title: Rendering expectations
section.draft-comment:
The following statement was written as if RFC-level "must" was used, but was not marked with RFC. I've added the RFC notation; if this is not meant to be "MUST" then we need to find alternate wording.
We should probably also use a clearer definition of "Processors" in this context, as an editor is a processor that should not be forced to strip the content from displaying.
Update 2020-10-19: moving the "must strip" language into a rendering section. This is about not *rendering* the element.
section.p: Processors MUST strip this element from output by default. The content of required-cleanup is not considered to be publishable data.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: Processor options might be provided to allow a draft view of migrated content in context.

section.title: Attributes
section.p:
The following attributes are available on this element: (with a modified definition of translate, given below), and the attributes defined below.
remap Specifies information about the origins of the content of the required-cleanup element. This provides authors with context for determining how migrated content was originally encoded.
translate Specifies whether the content of the element should be translated or not. The default value for this element is "no"; setting to "yes" will override the default. The -dita-use-conref-target value is also available. The DITA architectural specification contains a list of each OASIS DITA element and its common processing default for the translate value; because this element uses an actual default, it will always be treated as translate="no" unless overridden as described.

example.title: Example
example.p: In the following example, an HTML document that used the center element was migrated to DITA. Because DITA has no clear equivalent element, the content is stored in required-cleanup until it can be marked up appropriately.
example.codeblock: <section> <title>Using the display</title> <required-cleanup remap="center">If you cannot read your display, see "Adjusting the language setting" before you continue.</required-cleanup> </section>
